item.title: Icebreakers with...Olympic Champion Surfer Carissa Moore
item.description: I’ve been on a surf trip here but it was over 10 years ago, and I have some of the best memories from surfing this spot. What’s the world of competitive surfing like? In Tokyo, Hawaii native Carissa Moore won the gold medal for the US in surfing’s first ever Olympics. But being conscious of and in tune with your own mental health, not being afraid to ask for help, and taking the time you need to feel through that space is super important. If you could compete at any surf spot around the world, what would it be? I hope it opens up surfing to a broader audience and can bring more people in, whether that's by inspiring someone to try surfing for the first time, or motivating them to choose their own path.

item.title: Census Data Shows White Population Dropped in the US for the First Time
item.description: Cities are getting bigger while rural areas empty out: “Population growth was almost entirely in metropolitan areas,” the US Census Bureau’s Marc Perry said. Still, that growth has slowed down: The US population increased 7.4% from 2010 to 2020, the lowest growth rate since the 1930s.  The government dropped the first detailed results from the 2020 count yesterday, revealing a country that’s more racially diverse, urban, and Phoenician than the previous tally a decade ago. The non-Hispanic white population dropped for the first time on record (2.6%), falling to its lowest share of the total population on record.

item.title: Return to the office? An argument for, and against
item.description: After 17 months of working at home in sweatpants amid a pandemic, should we dig out our work clothes and return to the physical workplace? And so I think we'll be much more flexible going forward when people say, Hey, can I work from home on Friday? Before COVID-19 there was a small remote office in Los Angeles, a central office in New York, and a few individuals working elsewhere around the country. But I do know that I’m going to want to continue to have work-life balance, and that includes being able to leave the home and get to the office and activate that part of my brain and identity. I think we’ve all seen firms—particularly in the finance industry—coming out and saying, OK, everyone needs to be in the office two or three days a week.  But a number of people have been like, really? Morning Brew asked three business professionals—one startup CEO, one mid-level manager at a Fortune 500 financial services company, and one large-company executive who’s about to become a parent—to share their thoughts.  So, I want to set a baseline that you're supposed to come into the office five days a week. When I'm at the office, I know that all my teammates and I are working toward the same thing. You want to be back in an office full-time, even with the baby on the way? Even if it's a different project, there’s a common bond of people working toward this shared mission and vision. I think it has something to do with not working on the same objectives.  I also ruled out hybrid and remote working because there’s far less opportunity for real face-to-face connection. And I think that’s a mistake because in the end you’re going to find a line that satisfies no one.  Throughout COVID-19 we learned that for certain types of work, some people are actually more efficient by not being disrupted in the office. And while I don’t think there are zero benefits to working in the office, where I come down pretty hard is the idea of mandating office or location time based on some arbitrary quota. A company is not a place that fits everyone, at every stage of their life. It was always understood that working from home was done occasionally, when you had a doctor’s appointment or something along those lines. More than two-thirds of them thought workers needed to be in-office at least three days per week; just 5% believed company culture would remain intact with a fully remote workforce. The argument for flexibilityBy Lauren Friend, senior director of learning and enablement, EvolveI'm a people person. The kind where you think, I'm going to walk by their desk and say hello...  My team has been fully remote for a year and a half and we've been exactly as efficient or more efficient than we were when we were in the office.  Ultimately, my biggest piece of advice for other organizations is if you put your people first, the rest is going to figure itself out. There are some people who moved during COVID-19, and that's different. He was full-time, five days a week in the office. I like to get up and move, to be in one corner of the office for this meeting and then bounce to another area for the next one.

item.title: The Biggest Changes To the Post-Pandemic Workplace Will Be Invisible
item.description: If we look at a) Sydney, Australia, and Nottingham, UK, which have intermittently resumed office work and b) US companies’ latest plans for post-pandemic office space, it’s clear most workplaces will look more like futuristic WeWorks than Mr. Nobody’s White Room. offices will likely have stricter (and more obvious) protocols when employees first return, and like what’s currently happening in Australia, they may have to toggle back and forth between fully open and shut down until Covid-19 flare-ups are under control. Google's blog shows off Camp CharlestonThe other way offices will get more fresh air to employees? Bottom line: From air filtration to green spaces, the office transformations discussed so far will be implemented to make employees feel—and actually be—safer from the spread of disease, especially Covid-19, while working at the office. Other changes will focus on accommodating newly hybrid workforcesMany workers who’ve spent the past 1+ years cooking elaborate breakfasts aren’t ready to return to microwaved oatmeal: 30% of employees would seek out a different job if their companies returned to fully in-office work following the pandemic, per a Mckinsey survey. but not so much that employees will have to battle for workspaces like they’re going full seagull on each other for kettle chips. It’s when employees “rent” a desk for the day, or hours at a time, and share it with other coworkers when they’re OOO. It depends on how many days each employee swipes in, which will vary by workplace. At Adtrak, employees will book their desks in advance through an app.

item.title: The new office politics? An ‘existential crisis’ for some
item.description: Lat speaks about a law firm that recently decreed employees must return to the office five days a week, only to be met with staff reaching out en masse to recruiters for jobs elsewhere. You may have heard of this described as the “hybrid” work environment, where some people work from home and others log on from a corporate office. The idea that office politics are winnable? “That might not be a bad thing because there are a lot of artificial deadlines of, ‘I want this on my desk first thing in the morning’ by bosses who, lo and behold, don’t read that until the afternoon or the next day,” he says.  The shift to a virtual workplace was hard on office politics, too, particularly in hidebound industries like finance and law where remote work was relatively rare before the pandemic. For example, some workers are easing their sense of urgency around work projects, Lat notes, because it proved to be a charade all along. What I’ve seen and heard from workers is that now, when a manager steps in, they’re actually getting in the way of work.” “The invisible work women have always done is finally being recognized and appreciated because men had to experience it,” says Dawn Bovasso, a freelance creative director in Boston who has written about workplace policies’ effects on women. “The old way was really exclusive, excluding a lot of people: people of color, women, the differently abled—a lot of people,” she says.  If the performative politics of pre-pandemic office life are a bowl of ice cream, the pandemic surely melted it. “This new way is going to be inclusive. If the corporate world’s reaction to the COVID-19 pandemic turned 2020 into a mad scramble for new protocols defined by adaptive office tools like Google Docs, Slack, and Zoom, then its adjustment to a tentative recovery suggests a partial return to the office and semi normalcy. “A lot of office politics is over stupid stuff and a lot of that stupid stuff is tied to the physical environment: fighting over the corner office, talking so loudly on calls that coworkers can hear them down the hall, being bad at bathroom etiquette, vaping at your desk, leaving smelly food in the break room,” he says. The virtual environment has undoubtedly given workers more power over their supervisors. “It is challenging to replicate office politics in a virtual era, which isn’t a bad thing,” says David Lat, a longtime analyst of law firm culture and himself a former top-tier recruiter. “So much of politics arises from physical interaction, so if we have less interaction we have less cause for conflict and less need for politics.” True, the completely virtual environment that many people have been working in for 17 months has hardly been a cakewalk.
